topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces AEO as a major shift in search behavior and sets up Ethan Smith (Graphite) as an SEO expert to explain how to get recommended inside LLM answers.

topics.title: How big a change is AEO?
topics.summary: Ethan compares today’s AEO shift to earlier SEO upheavals (e.g., Panda) and argues this is the second-biggest change: search is becoming LLM summarization with new inputs.

topics.title: Defining AEO vs GEO
topics.summary: They define AEO/GEO as optimizing to show up as answers in LLMs; Ethan prefers “Answer Engine Optimization” because it’s narrower and clearer than “Generative.”

topics.title: Why LLM referrals are rising now
topics.summary: Lenny notes ChatGPT referrals surpassing Twitter; Ethan attributes the jump to increased adoption and more clickable answer surfaces (cards, maps, shopping) starting around January.

topics.title: AEO misinformation and anti-spam reality
topics.summary: Ethan responds to “just write great content” advice: everything can be optimized, but spam tactics will be detected and countered—similar to how Google evolved against spam.

topics.title: Webflow case study: what drives AEO wins
topics.summary: Ethan shares Webflow learnings: traditional SEO pages help, but LLMs reward being mentioned across many citations; YouTube and Reddit mentions were especially effective.

topics.title: Head vs tail: why startups can win fast
topics.summary: They explain how LLM ranking differs from Google: you need many mentions, not just the #1 link; early-stage companies can appear quickly via fresh citations, and chat expands the long-tail of questions.

topics.title: LLM traffic quality and conversion uplift
topics.summary: Ethan reports LLM-driven leads can be far more qualified, citing Webflow’s 6x higher conversion rate from LLM traffic versus Google search due to stronger intent and priming.

topics.title: Onsite vs offsite levers; why Reddit matters
topics.summary: Ethan breaks AEO into onsite (answering detailed product/use-case questions) and offsite (earning citations via video, UGC, affiliates, blogs). Reddit is heavily cited and must be approached authentically, not spammed.

topics.title: RAG vs training data: what you can influence
topics.summary: Ethan distinguishes core model training from retrieval-augmented generation (RAG). Most practical optimization targets RAG/citations because influencing training is slow and difficult.

topics.title: Core principles: topics, question research, citations
topics.summary: Ethan outlines key mental models: LLM answers are search+summarization; optimize by topic clusters, comprehensively answering follow-ups, researching questions via search terms and customer conversations, and building citation strategies by source type.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Great Question (UX research platform).

topics.title: Step-by-step AEO execution plan
topics.summary: Ethan gives an actionable workflow: derive target questions from paid/search data, track performance, analyze citation sources, build the right page types, answer follow-ups, and pursue offsite citations via affiliates, video, and authentic Reddit participation.

topics.title: Experimentation and team setup for AEO
topics.summary: Ethan warns most “best practices” are unvalidated; run controlled experiments with tracking to confirm what works. He recommends pairing SEO expertise with community/video skills for offsite citation work.

topics.title: Answer tracking and share of voice
topics.summary: They discuss AEO trackers as the analog to keyword rank trackers, but with variability across runs, question variants, and platforms. Measure share-of-voice and average rank across multiple surfaces and repeated queries.

topics.title: Which LLM platforms matter and why
topics.summary: Ethan explains citation overlap differs across engines (ChatGPT vs Google vs Perplexity) and argues it’s too early to bet on one winner; likely 2–3 major platforms will matter long-term.

topics.title: How AEO differs for B2B vs commerce
topics.summary: Ethan notes citation sources and clickability vary by category: B2B answers may be less clickable and require survey-based attribution, while commerce/local have shoppable cards where schema/reviews matter; early-stage should focus on citations and long-tail.

topics.title: Attribution pitfalls and content indexing tradeoffs
topics.summary: They cover how LLM influence can be misattributed as branded search or direct traffic, and why you should still allow indexing (even if blocking training) because you’re in the game regardless and competitors will benefit otherwise.
